div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE STIRRING OF "THE INFERIOR
div.p: RACES''

The trouble between Japan and the United States consequent on the anti-OrientalLsm of California form? the text of an important article in the last " Saturday Review " Our contemporary declares that a grave situation is arising throughout the world, and has to be faced by white men everywhere. "The determination to keep aloof from the coloured races is an instinct, bad or good, which seems inseparable from residence in their neighbourhood . . . The troubles which agitate the Western States have been in full blast in Australia for some years. With great difficulty the better-class Japanese are admitted and everyone remembers the recent legislation regarding the labour of our own coloured subjects on liners. Our South African possessions have legislated so as to place intolerable burdens upon any of our Indian subjects who desire to trade there. Canada shows a strong disposition to follow the example of Australia. The danger is not pressing there, but, if it were, the legislation would be similar and the Imperial Government would in the end find as much difficulty in preventing it as the Government at Washington will in resisting the racial prejudices of San Francisco. The same phenomena obtain under different conditions in India and Egypt. In fact, there is. little doubt that much of the ill-feeling latent among the upper classes on the Nile is due to the absolute refusal of British residents to treat Mohamed ans on a footing of social equality, and there is no real community of feeling between British and natives in India. . . This state of feeling has for long found its excuse in the term *inferior races,' and however ludicrous it may have seemed to anyone even remotely acquainted with the ancient civilisations of the East and the defective mental culture of large numbers of the conquering races, it yet found excuse in the military superiority of the white man. That assurance has now been rudely dispelled. We have seen an Asiatic people, comparatively small in numbers, inflict a smarting defeat upon the largest Empire in the world, and make peace with dignity and sagacity, as they made war without barbarity. Is it wonderful, then, that the brown man as well as the yellow is beginning to ask himself wherein his inferiority consists I The introduction of gunpowder killed the predominance of feudal chivalry upon the battlefields of Europe, and the acquisition by coloured races of arms of precision will ere long kill the fancied superiority of the white. .. The recognition of the

equality of all men before the law and of the right of all citizens to have a voice in the government of the country are principles which we have been ihstilling into the minds o^our subjects both in India and Egypt, and we now affect a pained surprise when the instruction bears its natural fruit. This is not confined to
one race or one religion.............. The trouble in

the United States is only a prelude to the far graver troubles that await this country', for the Englishman being far removed from the scene of disturbance can never appreciate adequately the spontaneous aversion that sunders the white man from the coloured. But the rulers of more subject-races than any other nation we especially are affected by the grave position of the racial question at the present time. We cannot hope for any sensible modification of their attitude by our fellow-countrymen and the resentment created by it may be suppressed among the coloured races, but is not extinguished. For the certain outcome of this all the ruling white peoples should be prepared,"

div.head: LAST DAY OF THE FAST-
div.p: According to the Mohamedan Calendar, the month of fasting ends today (the 29th day of Ramadan), and Beyram falls to morrow ; but should the new moon ot Shawal not appear this evening the Moslems of Egypt will have to fast to morrow, making the period of Ramadan 30 days, as it should be. In that case Beyram will commenoe on Sunday, and, consequently, the Khédivial reception will have to be postponed for a day.
The feast will be announced this evening by the firing of 21 gons, on the appearanoe of the new mooD.

div.head: DEATH OF GENERAL ROGERS.
div.p: LONDON, November 15. General Sir Robert Rogers, K.C.B., is dead. Lieut. Gen. Sir Robert Gordon Rogers, K.C.B., had seen servioe in E;ypt, having taken part in the memorable battle of Tel el- Kebir and the advance to Cairo, for which he received mention in despatches, besides the bronze star and Egyptian medal with clasp, and was decorated with the 3rd class Medji- dieh. He received his first commission in 1848 and served throughout the operations in Um beyla, 1863; Looudkhor, 1866 ; Black Mountain, 1868 ; Aimol Chubootra, 1876 ; Jowaki,- 1877-78, and Afghanistan (Ali Musjid, Logh- man Valley, Zymookhb) 1878-80, being frequently mentioned in despatches. From 1873 to 1884 he was commandant of the 20th Punjab Infiintry.He had a large number of medals, and was made A.D.C. to the late Qaeen in 1882

div.head: MEDITERRANEAN FEVER
div.p: The authorities of the Naval Dockyard at Malta have hsaed a oironlar to the employés drawing attention to the researches of the Mediterranean Fever Commission, and to the fleets which the commission has established in its endeavours to trace the caases of Mediterranean fever. It has been foond that the milk of both goats and cows frequently oontaius the lever germ in large numbers. The oemmission recommended the workpeople to abstain altogether from fresh milk and use only the tinned variety. A little while ago the military authorities forbade the introduction of fresh milk into barracks or quarters. This action has been followed by a remarkable diminution in the number of fever cases among the troops. A similar result has been obtained in the Naval Hospital, where goats' milk has been entirely tabooed.

div.head: LIBERALS AND EGYPT
VERNACULAR PRESS POLEMICS
div.p: In the course of an article dealing with his recent visit to London, the editor of "Al Mokattam" say^—
Thereupon we , were received tby the

Secretary of the Conservative Union. This gentleman promptly acoosed the Liberals or a false policy or of maladministration. They were destroying all that the Conservatives had built up—witness South Africa Had not Sir Edward Grey been at the Foreign Offiie they might have indulged iu all the extravagances asoribed to them by a section of the Egyptian Press He added, speakining of Lord Cromer, 'The whole nation, thanks to his reforms in Egypt, has abjolate confidence in him ; eqnal confidence is felt by the leaders without distinction of party ; Lord Cromer's position in Egypt is absolutely unassailable.'
"When we compare these statements with those of the Liberals we oannothelp laughing a little. Why do not some of our excellent editors hear and understand what we have beard and understood?

"The Liberals tell os that their confidence in Lord Cromer, who is one of themselves, is unlimited, the Conservatives telles just the same thing. Aud our good editors in Egypt know for a faot from certain persons better informed than the Liberals and the Conservatives, e.g., Mr. Blunt, the editor of 'Al Lews' and several dismissed officials,that Lord Cromer is only coming back to put his papers in order, pack up and retire, a beaten man.
"All who disagree with this view are the foes of the Moslems and the patriots. Judge for yourselves, Egyptians!"

"Al Lewa," of course, has much to say on this subjeot. For ourselves, we wonder whom Mustapha Pasha Kamel met in England : Mr. Robertson, whom he failed to persuade to come out here, Mr. Wilfrid Blunf, who forms a political party of his own, and a limited number of Radicals who gave him a dinner. We are not aware that the Nationalist leader met Sir Edward Grey, Sir Henry Campbell- Bannerman, the editors of the prinoipal daily papers, the Ministers,—in faot, the leaders of British thought. He now assails tbe "dakhil" —"les intrus," i.e. the Editor of "Al Mokat- tam." with the questions : Where have you been ? Whom did you see ? We never saw you in town ?
"Mutato nomine de te,
Fabula narratur."

Who, but the few enthusiasts we have mentioned, saw the author of the phrase "les intrus" in London ? What did the Egyptian tribune effect ? Paragraphs in two or three Radical papers, columns in the Egyptian Press and—voilà tout. Is Egypt a penny the better off after Mastapha Pasha's divagations ? Is any one better off hat the proprietor of the Carlton Hotel ?

"Partariunt montes"—with a vengeanoe.bat very "ridicalus Mas-tapha" is the product of their labour. Still there is always the solace of composing attacks on "les intrus." Like the poor, they are always with ap, and serve as whippiüg-boys on whom Mastapha Kamel can vent his annoyance. The most amusing thing abont it all is that they are not a penny the worse.

div.head: WRESTLING AT ABBAS THEATRE
div.p: There were five matohes on Taesday night, instead of the usaal four. Bigmann be,at Clément, the Belgian, hut not without difficulty, and only after 13 minutes. Limousin had a victory for once, over Sandorfi, in 16 minutep, both men showing tomnchadvantage.Cettlinger beat Van der Berg in 12 minâtes; it was good wrestling, but we had expected an even harder fight from the Dutchman. Milo only took 6 miuutes to finish Cylis. The last event, aud the shortest, was Pons and Noel. Noel had very little fun for his money ; his big oom- patriot threw him abont as he pleased, and the contest was over in abont half the time taken by Milo.

The wrestling on Wednesday night again consisted of five boats. Mehmet the African beat Stum in 6 minutes. Eigmann defeated the plump Swiss, Finiscb, in twice the time— 13 minutes, to be exaot. It was most amusing, Fiuisch being in unusually good form, with weird gesture?, facial contortions, and ferooions Berserk cries. Cilia beat Limousin after a long straggle in which both distinguished them selves. Sohackmann only took five minutes to finish off Milo, bat it was an exoiting contest, and at one moment Milo all bat had his man down.

But the event of the evening was Salama Hassib, the native amateur, against Clément, the Belgian, for a L.E 50 stake. After aboat 10 seconds sparring for grip Hassib had his man round the body and put him on his baok almost before we realised what was happening. It took about half a minute to finish the fall, which was doubtful, as Hassib had his hand under Clément's shoulder. Some of the speota tors hesitated at the referee's deoisioD, but it looked thorough enough. Hassib is tall, not so stout as most of the meD, and he evidently has great strength of arm. Clément seemed completely powerless in his grip.

div.head: THE KING'S BIRTHDAY
CELEBRATIONS AT BEYROUT
div.p: Bey rout, November 12.

On the anniversary of the birthday of King Edward, Sir Robert Drummond Hay received the congratulations of the Consular body, the Vali of Beyront, and the Governor General of Lebanon, as well as otherdistioguish- ed personages. IQ the evening Sir Robert and Lady Hay held a reception, and the fanotion was in every way a success. The iffuminations had a very charming effect. The rows o* lights on the long border of the high garden- wall and the baloony above, the flagstaff ropes turned into long gracefal lines of light, the large arabesque lamp with small pagoda windows of multi coloured lights, suspended above the monumental entrance, the two fine Arecaria trees on each side of it, state'y and straight and tall like Ethiopian sentinels, and the beautifal palmettos and rose bushes around, all presented a soene of oriental charm particularly consonant with the place, and the effect was emhanced by a soft autumnal air and a dear atanit sky.

The gnests repressnted principally the British and American colonies, constituted to a large degree by the missionary class. British missionaries from the outlyiog villages in the Lebanon attended, and one conld not help admiring the lively sense of patriotism that drew them together from such widely scattered places to celebrate under the Union Jack the anniversary of their Sovereign. Among the Americans, all of whom were members of the College Btaff, the President Emeritus, Dr. Daniel Bliss, already a historic personality, was a conspicuous figure.

American missionary effort has, for so many generations, been exercised with fraternal nnion towards a common goal, and nothing conld be more natnral than that they should be made to assemble on an oooasion of snoh supreme interest and give oommon expression to festive jabilation. Furthermore, in the East, where little distinction is made between English and Americans, and where both are considered as belonging to the one great English-speaking family, it behoves their representatives abroad to appear in the eyes of the people as one body representative of the moral and intelleotoal sway of the Anglo-Saxon race in the world. I believe everybody will cononr in tbe opinion that the pablio manifestation of snoh solidarity between the two great English- speaking peoples, co-operatiog in the same field ot moral and intelleotoal activity, tends to heighten their prestige and bring them ont more prominently still as th9 exponents of Western civilization and progress.

The fanotion was evidently conceived with jadioion8 foresight and ably planned oat. Besides the American colony there was a sprinkling of-Druse aristocracy. The Emir Tewfik Arslan, Kaimakam of the Chonf, and his brother, Emir Foaad, of versatile intelligence, Cassim Bey Ezzedine, sanitary inspector, and two distinguished personages of Rachaya, near Merj Eyonr, were invited. One of the two latter is said to 1)3 a man of great wealth, while the other is a well-known personage of the Dro8e nobility of that region. Let me parenthetically observe that even there plutocracy is beginning to vie wi*h ancestral aristocracy. Both of these native ohiefs were dressed in their oriental garb and the sumptuous flowing garments set off in a very picture.4qae manner the monotony of black evening dresses. Both are handsome and looked particularly dignified. 1 was informed that they are the companions of Sir Robert's hunting tours in the regions under their so-called vassal rule.

The presence of the Greek Consul General, Mr. Londos, and his charming wife, who is an intimate friend of Lady Hay, and is, indeed, a favoarite of high society, was likely to be regarded as a departure from the strictly national character of the fête. Bat the fact of Mrs. Londos having been brought up in England, and, what is more significant still, the very near relationship between the crowned heads of the two Kingdoms, may have made Mr. and Mrs. Londos feel jastly entitled to make a kind of "surprise" to their oolleagaes and friends and join in the celebration of a sovereign so closely allied to their own. Indeed, the sympathy which the English people have shown the Hellenic nation at a crucial period of the evolution of their national history has linked the two peoples into an abiding friendship which the great, fire-tongned bard, Byron, has immortalized in divine verse.

Many of the "toilettes" weie remarkably elegant, and Lidy Hay looked at her best in a fine manve roba with a very rich lace eoharpe. At the baginr ing of the evening tea and rich variety of cakes were served, .followed by lemonade and ices, and finally the traditional iced cbampagne for toasts to his Imperial Majesty. Before the invités began to take leave a group was jadiciously arranged in the hall, and a flashlight snapshot was taken of it. The photos will prove appropriate and precious mementoes of a not-to be forgotten event. The evening was throughout a mo*t plea sant one, and there was a general feeling of dignified ease which on'y a hostess like Lady Hay and a host like Sir Robert, eudowed with talent for social selection and verged in the ways of the "grand monde," can prodace.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE
"La Chatelaine
div.p: "La Cbâfelaine," by A. Capus, is an altogether pleasing piece. There is throughout an element of cleanliness and sincerity ; its interest never flags ; its dialogue is bright and replete with epigram, and there is jast s snffisient preponderance of comedy over tragedy to realise our hopes of a happy dénouement. Now-a-days an unhappy ending savoors much of suburban melodrama.

The action hinges ch'efly on a "non combatant," Jacques, the only child of Thérèse and Gaston de Rives, who, after 10 years of married failure, have decided on a divorce. Gaston having squandered their fortune, all that remains of Thérèse's dot is the heavily mortgaged and half-ruined château de Sauve* terre, which she is trying to sell to be able to live with her son on the proceeds. At the house cf her relations, the de la Baudières, she meets a M. André JoBsan, a cheery and astute being, possessed of much of the world's goods and knowledge. With a rapid transition from generous pity to fervent love, he prompt'y buys the château at a fabulous prioe and after some innocent demur on Thérèsé's part, they agree to marry as soon as the divorce pèrmits. In an admirable scene he overcomes her soruple8at accepting the high figure he intends to pay and calms her suspicions of the uncharitable motives the world will oorjure up regard ing the transaction. They are reckoning, however, without Mme de la Baudiè^e, a delightful character, with something of a Batsy Trotwood in her set resolution to accomplish her ever-changing purpose. Her husband, by jadioiously giving way to her, generally brings her determination to coincide with the dictates of common-sense. It is consistent with her nature that, being intent on seouring so good a "partie" as Jossan for her daughter Lucienne, she should try to conciliate M. and Mme de Rives and so frustrate Thérèse's project, only to finally veer round in favour of young de Neray's marriage with Lucienne. There is, however, a far more serious obstacle to Thérèse's ultimate happiness in the shape of her hnsband, a worthless individual, more selfi *h than villainou*, who oar. not brook the prospect of Tcérèse and Jacques' future wellbeing, contrasted to his own adverse situation The divorce lies in his power, and, in a stormy and bitter soene, he refuses to take proceedings unless Thérèse will consent to break off her proposed marriage with Jossan. No less em phatically does Thérèse soont the notioD, where upon Gaston revenges himself by kidnapping the child, over whom he has a legal right, and leaves Thérèse, who adores her sod, in the throes of despair. She is partly consoled by Jossan, who undertakes to recover the boy, and,when the two men are confronted, manages with infinite tact and courage to rouse spark of liberal sentiment in de Rives by getting him to restore the child and go on with the divorce suit.

8uch is the bare plot, in itself diverting enough, but in the hands of Mma Jane Hading, as Thérèse, with the very ab'e support of M. Arnaud, as Jossan, a veritable masterpiece. Jane Hading in the "Dami-monde" and Jane Hading in "L\ Châtelaine" are two totally différent beings ; the unscrupulous intrigante gives place to the simple, afFeotionate woman, devoted to her son and to her benefactor ; restraint is superseded by repose ; the painfully extorted confession is replaced by the mournful compliance with adversity, a compliance imposed by Thérèse's strict sense of honour. This, and far more, did Mme Hading impress upon her audience, who were thoroughly appreciative and fall ot enthusiasm at this excellent achievement. A lot might be said for M. A maud's JossaD,—throughout a spirited and convincing performance, which met with a good reception Saooess also attended Mme Aloime Leblanc and M. Ragoneau as M. and Mme de la Bau- d'ère ; bnt, as the sordid hnsband, M. Haute- rive might have made more of his part.

div.head: THE AFRICAN SOCIETY.
div.p: The eighth monthly dinner of the African Society was held last week at the Criterion Restaurant. Sir Harry H. Johnston presided, and among those present were Mr. George Wilson (Deputy-Commissioner of Uganda), the guest of the evening, Sir William Holland, M.P., Mr. H. Samuel, M P., Mr. Cath cart Wason, M.P-, Colonel Wathcrston, Professor Dunstan, Mme. Novikoff, Mrs. J. R. Green, and Mr. H. d'Egville (secretary). After the loyal toasts the chairman proposed the health of Mr. Gecrge Wilson, who, he observed, had been connected for 20 years with British East Africa. Mr. Wilson, in responding, described the gradual progress of the people of Uganda towards civilization, and paid a high tribute to the valuable work carried out by the industrial branch established by the Church Missionary Society The system of very moderate taxation which had been imposed on the country had been productive of great good, for it bad promoted a spirit of industry among the natives. Rubber and cotton oould be produced there^ in a bund auoe, and~~tie hoped that before long agricultural schools would be established. The im portsand exports together were valued last year at £3.000,000, as compare! with £97,000 in 19 2. Mr. Shelford, in moving a vote of thanks to the chairman, stated that the membership) of the society had risen during the lsst 12 months from 400 to 600. Sir H. Johnston, in reply, said that Uganda represented a new departure in African development. The people of England hid thought too much of African development as the founding cf colonies f or white men. They were now coming to understand that much oi their work between the Zambesi and the Sahara was a work of education of young countries.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Ibrshim Papha Fuad, Minister of Justice, came down from Cairo yesterday to Alexandria, where he will spend the Btyram holidays.
The other Ministers are expectfd to arrive here this evening, in order to attend the Khédivial reception to morrow morning.
General Thurneyssen Papha, A.D C. to the Khedive, is leaving Alexandria for Cairo on the 21st inst.
A subscription has been opened by a committee formed of officials of the Native Court of Appeal Cairo, for the purchase of a souvenir to he presented to Saad Pasha Zaghloul on tho
occasion ot his new appointment.
The German Emperor has conferred the Order of the Crown ot Prussia on Mr. Ladislas Gyürgyey, Austro-Hangarian Consul at Alexandria.
El Miralai Owen Bey, who bad intended going to England on leave for a few weeks, has now abandoned his holiday.

The Khedive has conferred the grade of Saliss, with the title of Bey, on Youssef Eff. Sameh, an official of the Ministry of War, who acted as Tarkish interpreter to the Egyptian delegates on the Sinai Boundary Commission.
Mina Bey Ibrahim has besn appointed president of the Keneh Tribunal
Mrs. Hewins left Sunday night train.
Lieut. E.A. Bradford, 1st Battalion King's Royal R fie Corp°, left Cairo on Wednesday for Khartoum, to rejoin the headquarters of his battalion.
Lieut. T H. Dimick, Inspector of Army Schools, left for Malta yesterday on completion of his inspection of the schools in Egypt.

We regret to announce the death of Sergt.- Major Clift, Mounted Infantry, who died in England on the 3rd inst., after a short illness. Sgt.-Major Clift was sergeant-major of the Moanted Infantry, Abbassieh, from 1899 to 1903, when he was transferred to the M.I. School in Ireland. He leaves a widow and three children.

Hockey in Saez will sustain a severe loss by the departure of Mr. N. L9 Rougetel for Zanzibar. He may truly be oalled the "Father" of Suez hookey, which, under his able captaincy, attained a high degree of excellence. Ubiquitous on the field of play, untiring in his Bxertions, ever cheeiful, vigilant, a veritable Napoleon of hockey, his inspiring "Banzai" will be mi »sed for years to come in local contests. We wish Mr. N. Le Rougetel every success and prosperity in his naw sphere.

div.head: THE PLAGUES OF AFRICA-
LOCUSTS IN ERYTHREA.
div.p: It is stated that the devastations of locusts in Erythrea have had a ferions effeot in the Colony. The insects swarm by hnndreds ot millions in clouds so dense as to shut out the rays of the sun over wide tracts of country, where every vestige of vegetation has disappeared. It is the table lands 01 Ethiopia which have suffered with exceptional severity. The swarms seem to have originated in the Nile Valley, and to have been wafted northeastwards by high winds. From Ethiopia some of the swarms drift towards the Red Sea, Egypt, and the Mediterranean.

div.head: JORDAN WATER FOR BAPTISMS.
div.p: Colonel Clifford Nadand, an American officer who has acqoired a concession from the Turkish Government of the sole right to supply water from the River Jordan, is the first concessionnaire of the kind in the annals of monopoly. The water is to be exported in barrels, under official seal, for baptismal purposes. The main snpply will go to the States, where, it seems, people are particular about the contents of a font.

The same care used to be exeroised in England, in the case cf Royal infants. Her present Majesty was baptised in water from the Jordan. Bat its use, even for exalted recipients cf the rite, has ceased to be de rigueur. That the 1 ew Jordan Trust thould, as it appears to do, contemplate doing a wholesale business in baptisms, speaks well for tbo American birth rate, aud should accordingly enjoy the Presidential sanction,

Several French newspapers continue to comment on the visit of Herr Tsohirschky to the Vatican, pretending that he moat have asked tor its intervention on the Polish question. According to information from an authorized source, this news is absolutely without foundation. Herr Tschirsohky, in his negotiations, did not touch upon Polish affairs. It is true tint after his departure the Government was forced to send to the Vatican a memorandum on the situation of the Polish schools, by its envoy, refuting the false reports emanating from a Polbh source. The support of the Vatican has not been asked for, nor has the least wish for it been expressed. The Government has no need for intervention on its part. As for the relations existing between the Vatican and France, Germany observes extreme reserve.
It is thought here that the confliot oaueed by the law of separation is only transitory, and that sooner or later a reconciliation will be effected. (Reuter)

div.head:
GERMAN FOREIGN POLICY
NO FEAR OF ISOLATION.

div.p: Prince von Bulow added that Germany saw no reason to be disturbed at the prospective Anglo-Russian settlement of Central Asian questions. Germany would continue to care fully cultivate her relations with Japan. Her aims in the Far East were purely economic, the attainment at which depended on the maintenance of peace. He conoloded that Germany need not fear isolation if she kept her swoTd sharp. (Renter)
The European Preçs comments favourably on Prince von Bnlow's speech. (Hawn)

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON IN CENTRAL AFRICA
div.p: In a review of the cotton growing industry in the Central African Protectorate, the "British Central Africa Gazette" states that daring this last financial year cotton headed the list o exports, the quantity sent out being a little over 346 tons. Although the area under cotton has shrunk from 21,900 acres to 10,012 acres, the export is expected to be greater than last year, in spite of the bad growing season. The estimated production is 432 tons. This remarkable shrinkage of the area under this crop is easily explained. In the previous season hundreds of acres were planted with varieties of cotton altogether unauited to the prevailing climatic conditions, and thus gave a dis appointing yield. Planters also undertook to grow large areas without the requisite know ledge of the management of this special crop. The report continues:— 'The prospects oi the country are most encouraging. Cotton cultivation will steadily expand, as the staple produced is good. As much as 9 L per lb. has been obtained for it, whilst 81 and 8£d. are common figures for the Egyptian type. The 'Kidney' cotton has been selling at 8d., and the American Upland has averaged 7d. per lb,

"This country, as far as European cultivators are concerned, may be roughly divided into two parts—the river level?, and the Highlands. The Egyptian type of cotton is grown on the lower levels, and the American Upland in the Highlands. In the last-named district a comparatively short growing season has to be contended with, so that planting mast be done at the earliest possible opportunity. On the river levels irrigation mast be practice owing to the successful with irrigation and good cultiva tiou. If irrigation water be not available, earlier planting is essential."

div.head: JEWISH ANTIQUITIES IN EAST LONDON
div.p: Canon Barnett, of Toynbee Hall last week opened in the Whitechapel Art Gallery, a novel exhibition, whir h it is hoped will have the effect of drawing the Christian and the Jewish communities into closer touch.

All the articles on view relate to Jewish art or antiquities and for Biblical students almost every exhibit Iihr a lésion. There is included the stone from the Temple at Jerusalem which was presented to Sir Moses Monte- fiorc by the Governor of that city. A signet ring on view is said to have belonged to a contemporary of the Prophet Nehemiah. The Chief Rabbi (Dr. Adler) and Canon Barnett both expressed the strong hone that the exhibition would have the fffoct of bringing abont a better understanding between Jew led Geutile

div.head: ABDUL HAMID'S SUCCESSOR
MANIFESTO OF YOUNG TURKISH PARTY
div.p: The chief leader of the ' Young Turk," Ahmed Riza, who is living in exile at Paris, declares that the Sultan, in spite of his recent partial recovery, has but a short time of life/ before him. IPs complaint is stated to be cancer of the kidneys, from which incurable illness his brother, Kemaleddin, died within six months.

"The death of Abdnl Hnmidf who refuses all reform to his subjects," Ahmed RV. writes, "is waited for impatiently. That event will be a grand festive for all Ottomans, because it will be their deliverance and mark the beginning of an epoch of progress."

"The disappearance of such a scourge," the Young Turkish leader continues will, however, not be without grave dangers and difficulties, and regards his successor and the conn try at large. Every 'Blank Band' of adventurers will try to get a hand in. The Bulgaria! 'comitadjis' will burn their last cartridge attain their object. Russia seems to be ready to throw oil on any conflagration that may arise. Murderoas henchmen, disguised as Ulemas or soldier», will attack the houses of Christians, and then such an event will be denonreed to the Powers as crimes committed by far.at'C Mnssnlmans. so as to bring abont intervenMon. Au attempt may even be made to insist on the choice < f a Sultan under age. in order to facilitate European intervention."

In view of such possibilities a proclamation, or manifesto, has been issued, in which the whole reign of Abdul Hamid is branded. It declares that the accomplices of the Sultan intend placing his fourth son, the youth Burhane Idir, on the throne and at the head of the KhdiLt°, to the detriment of the real heir, Prince Mohamed Reshad Effendi.

"The rights of the latter," the manifesto says, "must be defended with all our strength, and even at the price of oar blood. The happiness and the future of our counttry depend on the suppression of the despotic rule and on the application of the Constitution of 1876, which was reoognised as an imprescriptible right of the nation, but was perfidiously done away by Abdul Hamid. Our Christian and Massnlman compatriots must, in common accord, demand to have this Constitution again pat in force, so as to give the country once more its vitality, for the sake of the people's welfare." !

div.head: NEW HARBOUR WORKS AT MALTA.
div.p: The two new dry docks in the Grand Harbour, Malta, which have been under construction for nearly six years, are now completed, and constitute an important part of the programme of improvements now being carried out by the Admiralty at that port. They are (says the "Times Engineering Supplement") situated in a well-protected position at the top of French Creek, and are 790ft. and 550ft. long respectively, with a width of 120ft. on the cope and a depth of water on of 35ft. The larger dock can be div: two docks by means of an inner caisson both docks can be lengthened by 40ft. when necessary by moving the caissons to the outer stops. Although the contractors, Messrs. S. Pearson and Son, have completed their portion of the work, the formal opening is not likely to take place for a month or two. The work has been difficult and costly, the docks having been excavated ont of solid rook, and the rock fissured to such an extent that the contractors were practically compelled to pomp water direct from the Mediterranean So great was the quantity of water to be dealt with that on more than one occasion the docks were flooded and work had to be entirely suspended for pumping operations, while at one period for several months in succession the plant was pumping over 40 million gallons or water every 24 hours. This operation necessitated the employment of a pumping plant (probably the heaviest employed on any contract c-f this kind) which includes seven Lancashire boilers, 300 h.p.,and eight sets of heavy rocker pumps, in addition to a large number of portable engines and pumps of all classes. Apart from the trouble with the water, the work of construction was carried on by such a force of workmen that the smaller dock was practically built within eight months, and, in addition to the native workmen, it was necessary to import labour from both Italy and Spain, as many as 3,000 men being at one time employed upon the work. The oonstmotion called for the use of over one million feet of granite, moat of which was imported from Sardinia, whilst some cune from the Alps. The docks are a great addition to the resources of ths port, and will easily anormal'(Ute the largest ships at present afloat. The intention at the time the construction of the docks was decided upon was to make Malta a more important naval station than hitherto, and the then existing docks were too small for the ships to use the port, The docks are being fitted with the most modern appliances for repairs. Among other works at present being carried oat is the construction of two breakwaters at the entrance to ihd Grand Harbour, which is now exposed to the Gregale wind?.The larger breakwater will extend 1,400ft. from the shoie, and shorter one of 400K is already constructed. Other improvements now being carried out by the Admiralty are new wharf walls and additional berth accommodation, which have necessited a large amount of dredging. The whole scheme when completed will constitute a very important addition to the port. The work has been under the special superintendence of Mr. Ernest Pearson. The Admiralty have been represented by Colonel Sir E Riban, under whose direction the work has been carried out, and Mr. Cartwright Reid, who during the latter stages of the work has acted as superintendent civil engineer.

div.head: BAGDAD RAILWAY EXTENSION.
div.p: It is announced that work will begin in March next on another link of the Bagdad railway line. The new branch will run from Balghmlu. the terminus of the existing line, south of KonD, to Adana.

HerrR tter, the manager of the undertaking, has, says the "Manchester Guardian" correspondent, already arrived at.Constantinople, and two German engineers have get oat to study on the spot the question of taming Mersina, which is connected by a short line with Adana, into the port of discharge, or of constructing a new harbour at Yamurtalik, a few miles from Medina.

div.head: ANOTHER LIFE SAVED
BY DOAN'S BACKACHE KIDNEY PILLS.
div.p: Stone and Kidney Disease.
Mrs. Catlin, at 19, Hinton Road, Herne Hill, London, England, who is an old lady, says

"1 was ill altogether about four years from what the doctors (and I had to see three of them) told me was stone and kidney disease," said Mrs. Catlin. ' I had dreadful pains, not only in my back, but in my left sid , frequently headaches and dizziness came over me, so that I could scarcely see ; I couldn't even manage to thread my needle. My tongue was coated, and there was a terribly bad taste in my month.

"Things went from bad to worse, and at length I was obliged to take to my bed, where I lay for over 10 months. The last time I went out before this I fainted in the shop where I was making a purchase.
"At last the doctor said there was no hope for me unless I went into hospital; at that time 1 couldn't walk without support.

"I went into hospital, but I got no better and the doctors decided that it was necessary I should undergo an operation ; I didn't like the idea of this, and left the hospital, the doctors telling my husband that I couldn't possibly get over my illness. Before I came ont I had to sign a paper taking upon myself all risk for doing so.

"That same night I began using Doan's Backache Kidney Pills, and they quickly proved to be just what was needed. In a week or two, instead of being a helpless cripple, I was able to get about a little, and even to help with the housework. Gradually I picked up my strength, all the pains disappeared, and I felt all right again.
"I have had no return whatever of the kidney disease since Doan's Pills cured me, 10 months ago.'
Doan's Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at 13 P.T. per box.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: I he 2nd Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment, under the command of Brevet Colonel F. W. N. McCracken, D.S.O., will embark at Alexandria on the 1st December on the S.S. Dongola for coi.veyanoe to the port of Karachi, from where the battalion will proceed to Subathu, to be stationed. Sobathu is a very healthy station within view of Simla.

The command of the 2ud Battalion R;fle Brigade (recently in Egypt) at Chanbattia, has just changed hand?, Major II. P. King Salter, second in command of the 4th Battalion at Malts,having been promoted iiuiteDant colone commanding in succession to Colonel H. F. Mu Wilson, whose tenare had expired. The ne 1 chief of the 2nd Battalion has eerved in th Green Jaoketa for nearly 27 years, and has the North West Frontier Campaign, 1897 98 (medal with clasp) to his credit. The vacant majority has gone to Captain H. D. Rosp, 3rd Battalion, Devonport. Mwjor Ross gets the crown at slightly over 16 years' service.
Lieutenant F. B. Nixon, Inniskifling Dragoons, has been placed on daty with the Egyptian draft of his regiment, which will embark for Cairo on the 1st prox.
L'eutenant A G. Tritton, Coldstn am Gnards, has been appointed adjutant of the Guards depot. Caterham.

The reservists of the Royal Horse Artillery and the Royal Field Artillery are to be called up for drill with the new 15-poonder and 18 pounder quick firing guns with which the batteries of those arms are being re-armed.

The Highflyer, Captain Christian, was completed to full complement yesterday to replace the croiser Fox, Captain J.B. Eastace, on the East Indies Station. Owing, however, to some defects in her engine room, the Highflyer will not leave Devonport tor some time. When previously on the East Indies Station, the Highflyer bore an indifferent reputation for speed, and she frequently came under the category of "lame ducks."

l'Express Nile Steamers Co. pour son service de passagers.

On suit avec iatérêt le développement de cette Société, qai, en que'qnes mois, a réussi k établir ud service de transport de marchandises dont les résultats dépassent toutes les espérances, et un eervica de passagers, dont le suocès est d'ores et déjA assuié.

Il y a lieu de noter que ces lésaltats ont été atteints avec un capital insignifiant : trente mil'e livres. C'est pourquoi l'on peut s'attendre k une forte baosse sur l'actioD, qui est encore aux environs du pair et constitue l'un des meilleurs placements que l'on puisse faire en ce moment.
Nous détaobous d'une lettre de Londres, en date du 9 Novembre, le passage suivant:

"La situation monétaire reste toujours res serrée, mais on sent tout de même nn peu moins de gêne que la semaine dernière et ou ne oraiut plus que la Banque songe k élever son taux d'escompte k 7 % car, d'une part, les nouvelles d'Amérique sont plus rassurantes et, d'autre part, on annonce que la Btoqie de France vient d'autoriser la sortie de £200,000 destinées k l'Egypte. C'est lk un symptôme qni porte k croire que Londres ne sera plus appelé,
oette a jnée, à ravitailler le marché égyptien.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: The Money Market,

The Old Woman of Threadneed'e Street is more comfortable. Slowly bat sorely the monetary situation is improving. The Bank statement showing a proportion of gold reserve of over 38 percent. was better than was expected, and it is hoped that even if the American Treasury makes no advances, and no other outside relief comes, the arrivals of gold from the Cape, of which £1 675,000 is now on the way, will meet any further demands likely to sbe made. The crisis may be considered past, and the moderation shown on all hands, particularly in the reduction of speculation on the Stock Exchange, is now fully recognised. It is unnecessary to say that the discount houses have been in a very awkward position during the past few weeks, and even to day the price at which rang bills can be negotiated shows a very large margin. Fur four months' bills 5j per cent. is taken, but no one will bring in long bills who can afford to hold them for the present. The position is not clear enough even yet to enable the discount houses to see ahead with any certainty. Naturally, therefore, they charge outside rates.
The Stock Markets.

This week the stock markets have pursued the very even tenour of their way, and in no section has there been any degree of excitement; even the New York elections stimulated but a moderate amount of interest. The reason for this apathy is not far to seek. The end of a long and dull account is at hand, and had there been any inclination to open new commitments, these would have been checked by the prospect of high contango rates following on the six per cent. Bank rate. As has been the case for some time past—in tact, since the drain of gold from the Bank of England commenced the week opened with further fears of dearer money and a higher rate, but these gradually evaporated, the action of the Bank of France in releasing gold for Egypt helping to restore confidence. This improved feeling was further assisted yesterday by the publication of the return showing an increase of neiriy a million in the reserve, and the fact that the Bank rate remained at 6 per cent. he tone continues g >od, but as the settlement iu mining shares commences to-day, and in general securities at the beginning of next week, Btock and thare dealings are restricted within narrow limits.
Consols»

The gilt-edged market has been somewhat depressed, fears of money troubles and pe increase in the rate of discount operating un favourably. The price of Consols has moved irregularly, and the improvement in the reserved and the non-increase of the rate failed to impart strength. Consols leave off to night at 86$ to the account, at which figure they shown( change on our last.
Foreign Bonds.

There has been some talk of a new Russian loan. and it has been "au'horitat.vsly" stated ii Paris that the qnpstion has undo comiderabh progress there as the result of M. Isvolsky'i visit, and tho assurances he w.-s able to g v< sf er an interview with the Tsar. These rumours have naturally had the effect of checking tin boom in Russian seouriti s which had coot need for some days, and on Tuesday the Fou dropped } to 76 }, and the scrip (f the uc Five- jj to 6 discount. They close to night & 76 and 6$ discount. There has been a goc investment demand for the two serips of Japan' e<e Four-and a Half per cents, and the quotation for these has improved to 94£ and 92 j. The other series are dull.
Homo Ralls
Home railways made a good start, and there were several advances of £ to £, and in oue case, London Chatham and Dover 4 1/2

Preference, a gain of a full point was shown. Since the n, however, the market has relapsed int) a state of listlessness, excepting York D ferred, and the S ;otch section, which has fi-m on the improved prospects regarding a settlement cf the Clyde dispute. Caledonian Deferred are up to 31 £ and the Preferred to 73}, while North British are also better, the Preferred at 74 and the Deferred at 40f. There has been a demand for York Deferred, which is understood to be in connection with dividem anticipations, dealers counting upon two pei cent, as a minimum. .The shares close at 42}|
Americans.

The New York elections have, of course] been the cbief topic in the American market.] On election day Wall Street was olofed, and in consequence bosir was here in these shares was practically suspended. In anticipation that there would be a great amount of activity following the announcement of the resnlt of the contest for the Governorship of New York| State, a number of enterprising jobbers formed up in the "Street" at the unearthly hiur of 8 am. on Wednesday, but they were disappointed, the result coming in too late to be] of any use iu this direction, aud all that th early risers got for their diligence was this good-humoured chaff of the more leisure! section of the fraternity

The fact that Mr. Hughes obtained sneff a comparatively small majority— 55,000 or 60,000, oat of a total vote of about 2,000,000 —caused some disappointment i i the "House," for there was an uncomfortable feeling that had a democratic candidate lacking the personal drawbacks of Mr. Hearst been nominated he would certainly have been elected. The effect upon the shares was not, however, important. Wabash "B" Debentares dropped 2 points, but in the main the losses ranged from £ to b. Illinois were a good market, and gained 2j at" 180£.
To-day Americans have been flat, and there are several declines of 1 point, while Union Pacifies are l£ lower.
Egyptians.

The idleness prevalent in other sections has communicated itself to the Egyptian market, and this week there has been little business doing—a contrast with the activity prevailing daring the previous fortnight. Land and General Tras'-, however, h we been in good demand, and have risen to 4s. premium, the quotation last Friday being 2s. to 3s. Investment and Agency have also advanced to £ premium, but very few shares have changed hands. National B mk of Egypt have been 27$, but have sagged away to 27 1/4, while Agricultural B inks are easier at 9}. The bonds of the latter are a bad market at 89-90. Daira Sanieh shares are also dull again at 17£.

Quite a feature has been the strength of Egyptian Estates shares. There was considerable bidding in the market yesterday, and 2 ½ was freely offered, without sellers at this figure. It is satisfactory to note that Bearer shares were at a premium as compared with the Registered shares, 2 9/32 being offered for the former against 2 ¼ 3/8, with the Deferred at 15-17.

Delta Preference are unchanged at 12£, and Delta liar (1 & Investment, after being 4£ bii and seller*', dose firm at 4$. Kheiiv al Mai are up to 2, but there are no shares on thil side, ro »hii quotation is qui e nominal. U lioil Foncière i t 6$ ai d Land Bank at 9 changed. Corporation of Western Egypt at premium are a shade better,but Egyprian Markets and Salt & S ida remain at 1$ an 1 1}. B uk of Roumania are a flat market at 9.
Mining.

This market has been marking time pending the carry-over, which takes place to-day. Depression ruled after the announcement made by the Gold Fields Company that the dividend is passed notwithstanding the fact that the accounts show a balance £607,923 after p lyrnrnt of the debenture and un-farence interest. The directors consider it imprudent to declare a dividend in view of the uncertain state of the labour question brought about by the present Government, which is naturally a little tantalising to the shareholders. On this annooncement Gold Fields were offered down to 3}J, other leading shares giving way in sympathy. Rand Mines dose to-night at 6. East Rands at 4, and Modderfontein at 4Hl New Vaal River have had a sharp rise of 1/8 to 8 5/8.

There is absolutely no movement to record in Egyptian mining shares, which have been lifeless throughout the week. Nile Valleys remain at 5s. and Egyptian Mines at 3s. 6d. Um Rus 178; paid are Is. 6d. to 2s. 6d.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET
KSARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT
div.p: Liverpool, November 8, We have again had a dragging market to Spot Cotton, the actual sales being very small.! Prices are irregular, and the following are the changes in quotations Fair Brown is nn- changed ; Good Fair to Fine are redaoed £d per lb., whilst Good Fair and Fine Uppers are raised £ and Fully Good Fair and Good being reduced £ per lb. Features have been fairly active, and the following are the latest values :—
Nov. 9.4d Febr. 8.50 May 8.50
Deo. 8.58 Mar. 8.60 Jane 8.50
Jan. 8.51 April 8.50
American Futures.—The market this week has been very depressed, and the fall in prices, which has been as much as 31 points, has

been almost continuous. To-day there been some recovery, and closing prices are 20 @ 22 points below those of last Thursday. The chief causes of the decline have been the large crop movements, heavy "bull" liquidation, and extensive "bear" manipulation. Much has been made of the Bureau Celsius Ginners' report which is to be issued this evening in New York, and owing to large crop movements, very extreme estimates have been promulgated for market purposes. Conservative estimates are about 6,800,000 to 7 millions. Should 7 millions not be exceeded, we think t ie figures would be considered favourable to the market, and we should export a farther recovery in values. The South is holding firmly to the actual cotton, and considering the large sales made ahead fir shipment to Europe this month, buyers will probably have to pay the price demanded, which wonld in turn give strength to the contract markets.

div.head: NOTICE
SUDAN GOVERNMENT. DISPOSAL OF BUILDING SITES AT PORT SUDAN
div.p: The Sudan Government will shortly dispose by Tender of about 400 Building Sites at Port Sudan.
The sites will be Leasehold held at Annual Rents on Building Lease for Eighty Years from 1st January, 1907. Rents will be payable only from date of acceptance of Tender.
The Lease will be Perpetually Renewable at Revised Rents fixedin default of Agreement by Arbitration at the end of each term of years.
In fixing the revised rents the value of Buildings erected by Lessees will Not be regarded as a ground for Increase of Rent

Example : If a plot is leased ror a term of 80 years from 1st January 1907 then on the expiration of that term the Lessee will have a right (subject to observance of his convenant etc) to obtaia a fresh lease for a further period of 80 years at a revised rent, and so on in perpetuity. The revised rent will be calcul ated on the value the site would bear if it were vacant building lands.
Offers are invited of Premiums for the Pu
chase of the above mentioned leasehold sites.
All offers must be made by Tender, on the forms issued by the Sudan Government, and must be received at Khartoum not later than 1st January 1907.

Particulars of the sites offered, Plan of the Town, Conditions of Tender and Sale, Form of Tender, specimen Form of Lease, etc., will on and after October 1st 1906 be open to inspection at the following places during the usual business hours :
Khartoum : Office of Director of Agricul ture and Lands (T) and Office of Governor of Khartoum Province.
Cairo : Office of Sudan Agent (T).
Port Sudan : Office of Inspector (Government Office) (T).
Suakin : Office of Governor of Red Sea Province.
El Darner : Office of Governor of Berber Province.
Atbara : Office of Director cf Railways.
Alexandria : Office of Mr. Macpherson Grant.
Port Said : Office of Dixon Bey, War Office Representativ o
London: ^Office of Col. Western, Broadway Chambers, Westminster, and the Sudan Court, Imperial Institute.
Suez : Office of Capt. Falconer, War Office Representative.

For the convenience of intending purchasers the Conditions of Tender and Sale have been translated into Arabic and French and copies of the translations into either language will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. per copy at the Offices in the above list which are distinguished by a capital T.
Further information will be obtainable after the publication of the above-mentioned documents on applioation in writing to The Director of Agriculture and Lands, Khartoum.

div.head: GOUVERNEMENT DU SOUDAN
Concessions de Terrains a Batir
div.p: a Port-Soudan
Le Gouvernement du Soudan va prochainement disposer, par voie d'adjudication d'environ 400 parcelles de terrains à batir à Port- Soudan.

Les dites parcelles seront données à bail emphytéotique, pour une durée de 80 années à >artir du 1er Janvier 1907, moyennant loyer nnuel, à charge pour le locataire de bâtir. Le oyer ne sera payable qu'à partir de la date de l'acceptation de l'offre.
Les baux seront renouvelables à perpétuité moyennant un loyer variable fixé à la fin de chaque terme, soit d'accord, soit par arbitrage.
En fixant le nouveau loyer, la valeur des bâtiments élevés par le locataire ne sera pas considérée comme un motif d'augmenta ion de loyer.

EXEMPLES : Si une parcelle de terrain est louée pour une durée de 80 années à prtir du 1er Janvier 1907. Dans ce cas, à l'ex&piration de ce délai, le locataire aura un droit (à condition d'observer les conditions du bail) d'obtenir un nouveau bail pour une nouvelle période de 80 années, moyennant un loyer modifié, et ainsi à perpétuité.
Le loyer modifié sera calculé sur la valeur du terrain, s'il était libre de construction.

Des offres sont demandées pour les baux emphytéotiques dont s'agit ; ces offres devront mentionner la prime que le sounmsionaire est disposé à payer au comptant en sus des loyers annuels établis pour chacun des lots. La dite prime devra être payée en un seul versement à la signature du contrat de bail.
Toutes offres doivent être faites par soumission, sur les formules dressées par le Gouvernement du Soudan, et doivent être reçues à Khartoum avant le 1er Janvier 1907.

Le détail des terrains offerts, le plan de la ville, les conditions de l'adjudication et de la concession, la formule de soumission, spécification du bail, seront à la disposition du Public à partir du 1er Octobre 190G, aux lieux ci-après indiqués, durant les heures de bureau.
Khartoum*—Bureau du Directeur de l'Agriculture et des Terrains (T) et bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Khartoum.
Le Caire* Bureau de l'agent du Gouvernement du Soudan (T).
Port-Soudan*—Bureau de l'Inspecteur (Bureau du Gouvernement (T).
Souakim—Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province et de la Mer Rouge.
Wadi-Halfa—Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Haifa.
El-Damer —-Bureart du Gouverneur de la Province de BerberJ
Atbara—Bureau du Directeur du Chemin de Fer.
Alexandrie—Bureau de Mr. Macpherson Grant.
Port-Saïd—Bureau de F. Dixon bey, Représentant du Ministère de la Guerre.
Londres—Bureau du Colonel Western, Broadway Chambers, Westminster et le Soudan Court, Imperial Institute.
Suez—Bureau du Capitaine Falconer, Représentant du Ministère de la Guerre.

Pour la commodité des acheteurs éventuels les conditions d'adjudication et de concession ont été traduites en arabe et en français et des copies de ces traductions, dans les deux langues, peuvent être obtenues à partir du 1er Octobre 1906, moyennant payement de P.T. 5 par copie, aux bureaux mentionnés d ins la liste ci-dessus, qui sont suivis d'une lectre majuscule T.

Des informations supplémentaires peuvent être obtenues après publications des documents ci-dessus mentionnés, moyennant demande écrite adressée au Directeur de l'Agriculture et des Terrains, à Khartoum.
Aux bureaux marqués d'une astérisque, copies des documents pourront être obtenues à partir du 12 Octobre 1906, moyennant payement de P.T. 5 ou un ' 28497-2* -1

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6. Purchasers should see that the word 'THERAPION' appears on British Government Stamp (in white letters on a red ground) affixed to every package by order of His Majesty's Hon. Commissioners, and without which it is a forgery.
